text: I'm Jennifer from English with Jennifer.
Do you know what chitchat is?

Chitchat is about everyday things, like the
weather or sports.

Listen to some chitchat between my students
and me.
Do we have good habits or bad habits?
Did you go to sleep late or early last night?

I said, "I'm going to sleep tonight at 10
o'clock."
I'm going to sleep at 11 o'clock."
What time did you go to sleep?
Did you go to sleep late?
It depends when you wake up.
I had to wake up at 5:45.
I go to bed, but I couldn't sleep.

Sometimes you go to bed, but you can't fall
asleep right away.

Flavia, Andreia, and I talked about going
to sleep and falling asleep.
Do the ladies and I go to sleep early or late?

What time did Flavia go to sleep the night
before?
Do you ever have that problem?

Do you usually get a lot of sleep or very
little sleep?

I try to get about seven hours of sleep each
night.

A LOT, LITTLE, and ENOUGH are important words
to know.
Flavia and Andreia learned these words.

At first, they didn't know much, but now they
know a lot more.

They continue to study English at a language
school now.

I'm happy because I was able to film some
lessons with them.
MUCH, MORE, and SOME are also important words.

All of these words answer the question, "How
much?"
Do you know other words like these?

You can practice using quantifiers with Flavia
and Andreia.
What are you going to make?
And what are you going to make?
So, all of us are going to make something.
You're going to make the cake.
But these are all the ingredients.

Ingredients -- all the things we need to make
a cake, to make a salad, to make the soup.

We go to the store, get all these things,
and make our meal.

But maybe I have some things that you need,
and you have things that she needs, so we're

When we ask questions, we're going to use
the word "any."

For example, I know when I make a salad, I
need lettuce.
So, I'll be saying, "Do you have any lettuce?"

Oh! And then you could say, "No, I don't have
any."

So, we use the word "any" when we're asking
a question.
And you say, "No, I don't have any lettuce."
Then I'll ask do you have any lettuce?

We ask questions with "any," and we use the
negative with "any."
I need to go to the store and buy some.
Now we're going to see what we have.
I need to mix these up.

Another word besides "mix," especially with
cards, is "shuffle."

You can play cards [games], like poker, for
example.
These are all the things we have.

So, when we're counting, we can use "a" or
"an" or "one."
Um, do you have something for your soup?
I think you'll need some water.

I think you... you... so, you can say, "I'm
going to need some water."
"Some" is like, oh, a little bit.
Do you have something for your cake?
You have two cards with "oil" on it.
So, let's say each one is like a bottle.
Can we count one oil, two oils, three oils.

You have a tablespoon of oil, a bottle of
oil, so it's better to say, "I have some oil."
I have some oil, but do you need some oil?
No, I don't have any oil.
Well, you need to ask for some.
You can start with, "Do you have...?"

"Some" is a word we can use with things that
we can count: some tomatoes.

We can also use it with things we can't count:
some oil, some water.
Do you have anything to make your cake?
Do you think one egg is enough?
Well, how many eggs do you have?
Do you have any more eggs?

How many eggs do you think are necessary for
a cake?
How many eggs does she need?
Yeah, two or three, at least.
I have...Do you have any eggs?
Put your one egg down there.

And what's the question you're going to ask
her?
Do you have do you have any egg?

Now, if it's something countable, you'll use
the plural.
Oh, do you have any eggs?
You can give it to her.
A recipe tells you what to do.

It tells you what food you need and how to
cook it.

When we talk about food, we need the help
of quantifiers.
In our game, Andreia is going to make soup.

Some water, some oil, a little salt, one onion,
and many vegetables.

A LOT and SOME are for countable and uncountable
nouns.

A LOT is like MANY and MUCH, but we use "many"
with countable nouns and "much" with uncountable

We use "any" in questions and in negative
forms.
A LITTLE is for uncountable nouns.
Our salad won't have any eggs, but it's okay.
Our salad won't have any eggs.

I used "won't," which is the future, but it's
negative.
Our salad won't have any eggs.
You need it to wash the lettuce.
Okay, so I'll keep the water.
I need some water to wash the vegetables.

Okay, so our salad is going to have, um, a
hard-boiled egg, and I'll cut the egg up and
Do you have anything else for your soup?
I think I'll need some salt.
Do you think you'll need a lot of salt?

Do you need a lot of salt in your soup or
just a little?
So, you don't need a lot.
I don't need...I don't need a lot.

And when we say "a lot" in front of a noun:
a lot of -- a lot of water, a lot of salt.
I don't need a lot of salt.

No, you don't need a lot of salt, and I don't
think I need any salt.
All you have there are three eggs.
Do you think you'll need a lot of sugar?
You don't need a cucumber, do you?
This is the nice stuff on [top].
I don't need any icing on a salad.

I don't think you need any icing for your
soup.
It can be white, chocolate, pink...
And you spread it on your cake.
I need...I need any...I need some.
We use "any" for questions and negatives.
Can we say "a little cucumbers, a little tomatoes"?
How about...Some, but I'm talking even less.

So, with things that we can count, we can
say "a few": a few cucumbers, a few tomatoes.
Um, you might need a few carrots, for example.

Um, but "a little" for things that we cannot
count: I need a little vinegar, just a little.

Yeah, I might like to have at least one or
two carrots.
We can also say "a couple of carrots."
I'd like to have a couple.
Can I say "a couple of water"?

So, there are some words that are only for
countable things and some words only for things

Often in questions you'll hear, "How many
do you need?
Flavia is going to make a cake.

A couple of eggs, some flour, some sugar,
a little baking powder, and some butter.
I'm going to make a salad.

A lot of lettuce, some oil and vinegar, and
a few different vegetables: peppers, tomatoes,

If I really love vegetables, I can add several
different kinds: peppers, tomatoes, cucumbers,
A few is for countable nouns.
Several is more than two, but not many.

Let's practice using quantifiers with other
nouns.
Do we say "many socks" or "much socks"?
Um, I can have a pair of socks.
What else can I have a pair of?
A pair of -- things that we can count in twos.

You always have two socks because we have
two feet.
What else do we have a pair of?
A pair of pants because we have two legs.

That's one more quantifier for things that
we can count.

A pair of glasses, and when the sun is bright,
we wear a pair of sunglasses...because there
Um, do we say "a few shoes" or "little shoes"?
Do we say many dresses or much dresses?
Do I have many or much skirts?
Do I have many or a lot of makeup?

A lot of makeup, but you might say, like,
many...I don't know... containers, many tubes

of lipstick, but in general, it's just something...it's
a category.
I have some, or I have a few pairs of shorts.
I have a few pairs of shorts.
Can you ask Andreia a question?
How many pairs of jeans do you have?
Um, I have one, two, at least three pairs.
At least three, like, two black and one blue.
I have blue jeans and black jeans.
I think I have three pairs.
Um, do you have many shoes?
I have 15 pairs of shoes or more.
I have 15 pairs of shoes or more.

Note how we use quantifiers before nouns,
as in, "I have a lot of shoes.

I have many shoes, but we can also use quantifiers
alone, for example, "I have a lot.
How many photos do you have on your phone?
How many close friends do you have?
How much free time do you have?
Do you have a lot of time to study?
Five. How much money do you need to be happy?

Okay, so you're going to have some rice and
beans.
Are you going to eat any pork?

I'm not going to eat...I'm not going to eat
any.
You can say, "I'm not going to eat any pork.
I'm not going to eat any."

So, with quantifiers, we can put them before
a noun: some tomatoes, some oil.

Or we can just use them like a pronoun: I
need some tomatoes.

So, we can use it before a noun or just alone
as a pronoun.

So, the other way to think about it is how
much and how many?
So, we have a lot of, some, several, a few.

If you love nuts and you love cranberries,
you're going to have a lot of cranberries.
We need some cranberries and some [nuts].
And she's like, "Actually, I don't like nuts.
I just want a few nuts."
So, think of a few, several, some, a lot.

And same thing if, um, you want to talk about
things that you cannot count: a lot, some,
Are you going to add oil or salad dressing?
Some people like a lot of dressing.
Other people say, "No, that's too much."

So, a lot of salad dressing, some salad dressing,
or just a little.

Just a little salad dressing, a little bit
of salad dressing.

Okay, so in your mind, when you think of quantifiers,
think of what can you count, what can you

not count, and then think of how much and
how many?
From a lot to a little, a lot to a few.

In my office, I have many books, several pens,
a few notebooks, and I don't have any food,
